line: Introduction
label: heading

line: Apple designed the iOS platform with security at its core. When we set
label: paragraph

line: out to create the best possible mobile platform, we drew from decades
label: paragraph

line: of experience to build an entirely new architecture. We thought about
label: paragraph

line: the security hazards of the desktop environment, and established a new
label: paragraph

line: approach to security in the design of iOS. We developed and incorporated
label: paragraph

line: innovative features that tighten mobile security and protect the entire
label: paragraph

line: system by default. As a result, iOS is a major leap forward in security for
label: paragraph

line: mobile devices.
label: paragraph

line: Every iOS device combines software, hardware, and services designed to
label: paragraph

line: work together for maximum security and a transparent user experience.
label: paragraph

line: iOS protects not only the device and its data at rest, but the entire
label: paragraph

line: ecosystem, including everything users do locally, on networks, and with
label: paragraph

line: key Internet services.
label: paragraph

line: iOS and iOS devices provide advanced security features, and yet they’re
label: paragraph

line: also easy to use. Many of these features are enabled by default, so IT
label: paragraph

line: departments don’t need to perform extensive configurations. And key
label: paragraph

line: security features like device encryption aren’t configurable, so users
label: paragraph

line: can’t disable them by mistake. Other features, such as Face ID, enhance
label: paragraph

line: the user experience by making it simpler and more intuitive to secure
label: paragraph

line: the device.
label: paragraph

line: This document provides details about how security technology and
label: paragraph

line: features are implemented within the iOS platform. It will also help
label: paragraph

line: organizations combine iOS platform security technology and features with
label: paragraph

line: their own policies and procedures to meet their specific security needs.
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: are the platform for iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch.
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: System Security
label: heading

line: System security is designed so that both software and hardware are
label: paragraph

line: secure across all core components of every iOS device. This includes
label: paragraph

line: the boot-up process, software updates, and Secure Enclave. This
label: paragraph

line: architecture is central to security in iOS, and never gets in the way
label: paragraph

line: of device usability.
label: paragraph

line: The tight integration of hardware, software, and services on iOS devices
label: paragraph

line: ensures that each component of the system is trusted, and validates
label: paragraph

line: the system as a whole. From initial boot-up to iOS software updates to
label: paragraph

line: third-party apps, each step is analyzed and vetted to help ensure that
label: paragraph

line: the hardware and software are performing optimally together and using
label: paragraph

line: resources properly.
label: paragraph

line: Secure boot chain
label: heading

line: Each step of the startup process contains components that are
label: paragraph

line: cryptographically signed by Apple to ensure integrity and that proceed
label: paragraph

line: only after verifying the chain of trust. This includes the bootloaders,
label: paragraph

line: kernel, kernel extensions, and baseband firmware. This secure boot chain
label: paragraph

line: helps ensure that the lowest levels of software aren’t tampered with.
label: paragraph

line: When an iOS device is turned on, its application processor immediately
label: paragraph

line: executes code from read-only memory known as the Boot ROM. This
label: paragraph

line: immutable code, known as the hardware root of trust, is laid down
label: paragraph

line: during chip fabrication, and is implicitly trusted. The Boot ROM code
label: paragraph

line: contains the Apple Root CA public key, which is used to verify that the
label: paragraph

line: iBoot bootloader is signed by Apple before allowing it to load. This is the
label: paragraph

line: first step in the chain of trust where each step ensures that the next is
label: paragraph

line: signed by Apple. When the iBoot finishes its tasks, it verifies and runs
label: paragraph

line: the iOS kernel. For devices with an S1, A9, or earlier A-series processor,
label: paragraph

line: an additional Low-Level Bootloader (LLB) stage is loaded and verified by
label: paragraph

line: the Boot ROM and in turn loads and verifies iBoot.
label: paragraph

line: A failure of the Boot ROM to load LLB (on older devices) or iBoot (on
label: paragraph

line: newer devices) results in the device entering DFU mode. In the case of
label: paragraph

line: a failure in LLB or iBoot to load or verify the next step, startup is halted
label: paragraph

line: and the device displays the connect to iTunes screen. This is known as
label: paragraph

line: recovery mode. In either case, the device must be connected to iTunes
label: paragraph

line: via USB and restored to factory default settings.
label: paragraph

line: On devices with cellular access, the baseband subsystem also utilizes
label: paragraph

line: its own similar process of secure booting with signed software and keys
label: paragraph

line: verified by the baseband processor.
label: paragraph

line: For devices with a Secure Enclave, the Secure Enclave coprocessor
label: paragraph

line: also utilizes a secure boot process that ensures its separate software
label: paragraph

line: is verified and signed by Apple. See the “Secure Enclave” section of
label: paragraph

line: this paper.
label: paragraph

line: For more information on manually entering recovery mode, go to:
label: paragraph

line: https://support.apple.com/kb/HT1808
label: paragraph

line: System Software Authorization
label: heading

line: Apple regularly releases software updates to address emerging security
label: paragraph

line: concerns and also provide new features; these updates are provided
label: paragraph

line: for all supported devices simultaneously. Users receive iOS update
label: paragraph

line: notifications on the device and through iTunes, and updates are delivered
label: paragraph

line: wirelessly, encouraging rapid adoption of the latest security fixes.
label: paragraph

line: The startup process described previously helps ensure that only Apple-
label: paragraph

line: signed code can be installed on a device. To prevent devices from being
label: paragraph

line: downgraded to older versions that lack the latest security updates, iOS
label: paragraph

line: uses a process called System Software Authorization. If downgrades were
label: paragraph

line: possible, an attacker who gains possession of a device could install an
label: paragraph

line: older version of iOS and exploit a vulnerability that’s been fixed in the
label: paragraph

line: newer version.
label: paragraph

line: On a device with Secure Enclave, the Secure Enclave coprocessor also
label: paragraph

line: utilizes System Software Authorization to ensure the integrity of its
label: paragraph

line: software and prevent downgrade installations. See the “Secure Enclave”
label: paragraph

line: section of this paper.
label: paragraph

line: iOS software updates can be installed using iTunes or over the air (OTA)
label: paragraph

line: on the device. With iTunes, a full copy of iOS is downloaded and
label: paragraph

line: installed. OTA software updates download only the components required
label: paragraph

line: to complete an update, improving network efficiency, rather than
label: paragraph

line: downloading the entire OS. Additionally, software updates can be cached
label: paragraph

line: on a Mac running macOS High Sierra with Content Caching turned on,
label: paragraph

line: so that iOS devices don’t need to redownload the necessary update over
label: paragraph

line: the Internet. They’ll still need to contact Apple servers to complete the
label: paragraph

line: update process.
label: paragraph

line: During an iOS upgrade, iTunes (or the device itself, in the case of OTA
label: paragraph

line: software updates) connects to the Apple installation authorization server
label: paragraph

line: and sends it a list of cryptographic measurements for each part of the
label: paragraph

line: installation bundle to be installed (for example, iBoot, the kernel, and
label: paragraph

line: OS image), a random anti-replay value (nonce), and the device’s unique
label: paragraph

line: ID (ECID).
label: paragraph

line: The authorization server checks the presented list of measurements
label: paragraph

line: against versions for which installation is permitted and, if it finds a
label: paragraph

line: match, adds the ECID to the measurement and signs the result. The
label: paragraph

line: server passes a complete set of signed data to the device as part of
label: paragraph

line: the upgrade process. Adding the ECID “personalizes” the authorization
label: paragraph

line: for the requesting device. By authorizing and signing only for known
label: paragraph

line: measurements, the server ensures that the update takes place exactly
label: paragraph

line: as provided by Apple.
label: paragraph

line: The boot-time chain-of-trust evaluation verifies that the signature
label: paragraph

line: comes from Apple and that the measurement of the item loaded from
label: paragraph

line: disk, combined with the device’s ECID, matches what was covered by
label: paragraph

line: the signature.
label: paragraph

line: These steps ensure that the authorization is for a specific device and that
label: paragraph

line: an old iOS version from one device can’t be copied to another. The nonce
label: paragraph

line: prevents an attacker from saving the server’s response and using it to
label: paragraph

line: tamper with a device or otherwise alter the system software.
label: paragraph

line: Secure Enclave
label: heading

line: The Secure Enclave is a coprocessor fabricated in the Apple T1, Apple S2,
label: paragraph

line: Apple S3, Apple A7, or later A-series processors. It uses encrypted
label: paragraph

line: memory and includes a hardware random number generator. The Secure
label: paragraph

line: Enclave provides all cryptographic operations for Data Protection key
label: paragraph

line: management and maintains the integrity of Data Protection even if the
label: paragraph

line: kernel has been compromised. Communication between the Secure
label: paragraph

line: Enclave and the application processor is isolated to an interrupt-driven
label: paragraph

line: mailbox and shared memory data buffers.
label: paragraph

line: The Secure Enclave runs an Apple-customized version of the L4
label: paragraph

line: microkernel. This microkernel is signed by Apple, verified as part of the
label: paragraph

line: iOS secure boot chain, and updated through a personalized software
label: paragraph

line: update process.
label: paragraph

line: When the device starts up, an ephemeral key is created, entangled with
label: paragraph

line: the device’s UID, and used to encrypt the Secure Enclave’s portion of the
label: paragraph

line: device’s memory space. Except on the Apple A7, the Secure Enclave’s
label: paragraph

line: memory is also authenticated with the ephemeral key. On the Apple A11,
label: paragraph

line: an integrity tree is used to prevent replay of security-critical Secure
label: paragraph

line: Enclave memory, authenticated by the ephemeral key and nonces stored
label: paragraph

line: in on-chip SRAM.
label: paragraph

line: Additionally, data saved to the file system by the Secure Enclave is
label: paragraph

line: encrypted with a key entangled with the UID and an antireplay counter.
label: paragraph

line: Antireplay services on the Secure Enclave are used for revocation of
label: paragraph

line: data over events that mark antireplay boundaries including, but not
label: paragraph

line: limited to, the following:
label: paragraph

line: Passcode change
label: paragraph

line: Touch ID or Face ID enable/disable
label: paragraph

line: Fingerprint add/delete
label: paragraph

line: Face ID reset
label: paragraph

line: Apple Pay card add/remove
label: paragraph

line: Erase All Content and Settings
label: paragraph

line: The Secure Enclave is also responsible for processing fingerprint and
label: paragraph

line: face data from the Touch ID and Face ID sensors, determining if there’s
label: paragraph

line: a match, and then enabling access or purchases on behalf of the user.
label: paragraph

line: Touch ID
label: heading

line: Touch ID is the fingerprint sensing system that makes secure access
label: paragraph

line: to iPhone and iPad faster and easier. This technology reads fingerprint
label: paragraph

line: data from any angle and learns more about a user’s fingerprint over time,
label: paragraph

line: with the sensor continuing to expand the fingerprint map as additional
label: paragraph

line: overlapping nodes are identified with each use.
label: paragraph

line: Face ID
label: heading

line: With a simple glance, Face ID securely unlocks iPhone X. It provides
label: paragraph

line: intuitive and secure authentication enabled by the TrueDepth camera
label: paragraph

line: system, which uses advanced technologies to accurately map the
label: paragraph

line: geometry of your face. Face ID confirms attention by detecting the
label: paragraph

line: direction of your gaze, then uses neural networks for matching and
label: paragraph

line: anti-spoofing, so you can unlock your phone with a glance. Face ID
label: paragraph

line: automatically adapts to changes in your appearance, and carefully
label: paragraph

line: safeguards the privacy and security of your biometric data.

line: Touch ID, Face ID, and passcodes
label: heading

line: To use Touch ID or Face ID, you must set up your device so that a
label: paragraph

line: passcode is required to unlock it. When Touch ID or Face ID detects a
label: paragraph

line: successful match, your device unlocks without asking for the device
label: paragraph

line: passcode. This makes using a longer, more complex passcode far more
label: paragraph

line: practical because you don’t need to enter it as frequently. Touch ID
label: paragraph

line: and Face ID don’t replace your passcode, but provide easy access to
label: paragraph

line: your device within thoughtful boundaries and time constraints. This is
label: paragraph

line: important because a strong passcode forms the foundation of your iOS
label: paragraph

line: device’s cryptographic protection.
label: paragraph

line: You can always use your passcode instead of Touch ID or Face ID, and
label: paragraph

line: it’s still required under the following circumstances:
label: paragraph

line: The device has just been turned on or restarted.
label: paragraph

line: The device hasn’t been unlocked for more than 48 hours.
label: paragraph

line: The passcode hasn’t been used to unlock the device in the last
label: paragraph

line: 156 hours (six and a half days) and Face ID hasn’t unlocked the
label: paragraph

line: device in the last 4 hours.
label: paragraph

line: The device has received a remote lock command.
label: paragraph

line: After five unsuccessful attempts to match.
label: paragraph

line: After initiating power off/Emergency SOS.
label: paragraph

line: When Touch ID or Face ID is enabled, the device immediately locks when
label: paragraph

line: the side button is pressed, and the device locks every time it goes to
label: paragraph

line: sleep. Touch ID and Face ID require a successful match—or optionally
label: paragraph

line: the passcode—at every wake.
label: paragraph

line: The probability that a random person in the population could look at your
label: paragraph

line: iPhone X and unlock it using Face ID is approximately 1 in 1,000,000
label: paragraph

line: (versus 1 in 50,000 for Touch ID). For additional protection, both
label: paragraph

line: Touch ID and Face ID allow only five unsuccessful match attempts before
label: paragraph

line: a passcode is required to obtain access to your device. With Face ID, the
label: paragraph

line: probability of a false match is different for twins and siblings that look
label: paragraph

line: like you as well as among children under the age of 13, because their
label: paragraph

line: distinct facial features may not have fully developed. If you’re concerned
label: paragraph

line: about this, Apple recommends using a passcode to authenticate.
label: paragraph

line: Touch ID security
label: heading

line: The fingerprint sensor is active only when the capacitive steel ring that
label: paragraph

line: surrounds the Home button detects the touch of a finger, which triggers
label: paragraph

line: the advanced imaging array to scan the finger and send the scan to the
label: paragraph

line: Secure Enclave. Communication between the processor and the Touch ID
label: paragraph

line: sensor takes place over a serial peripheral interface bus. The processor
label: paragraph

line: forwards the data to the Secure Enclave but can’t read it. It’s encrypted
label: paragraph

line: and authenticated with a session key that is negotiated using a shared
label: paragraph

line: key provisioned for each Touch ID sensor and its corresponding Secure
label: paragraph

line: Enclave at the factory. The shared key is strong, random, and different
label: paragraph

line: for every Touch ID sensor. The session key exchange uses AES key
label: paragraph

line: wrapping with both sides providing a random key that establishes the
label: paragraph

line: session key and uses AES-CCM transport encryption.
label: paragraph

line: The raster scan is temporarily stored in encrypted memory within
label: paragraph

line: the Secure Enclave while being vectorized for analysis, and then it’s
label: paragraph

line: discarded. The analysis utilizes subdermal ridge flow angle mapping,
label: paragraph

line: which is a lossy process that discards minutia data that would be
label: paragraph

line: required to reconstruct the user’s actual fingerprint. The resulting map
label: paragraph

line: iOS 2018iOS Security Guide—White Paper | January 2018
label: paragraph

line: of nodes is stored without any identity information in an encrypted format
label: paragraph

line: that can only be read by the Secure Enclave, and is never sent to Apple
label: paragraph

line: or backed up to iCloud or iTunes.
label: paragraph

line: Face ID security
label: heading

line: Face ID is designed to confirm user attention, provide robust
label: paragraph

line: authentication with a low false match rate, and mitigate both digital and
label: paragraph

line: physical spoofing.
label: paragraph

line: The TrueDepth camera automatically looks for your face when you wake
label: paragraph

line: iPhone X by raising it or tapping the screen, as well as when iPhone X
label: paragraph

line: attempts to authenticate you to display an incoming notification or when a
label: paragraph

line: supported app requests Face ID authentication. When a face is detected,
label: paragraph

line: Face ID confirms attention and intent to unlock by detecting that your
label: paragraph

line: eyes are open and directed at your device; for accessibility, this is
label: paragraph

line: disabled when VoiceOver is activated and, if required, can be disabled
label: paragraph

line: separately.
label: paragraph

line: Once it confirms the presence of an attentive face, the TrueDepth
label: paragraph

line: camera projects and reads over 30,000 infrared dots to form a depth map
label: paragraph

line: of the face, along with a 2D infrared image. This data is used to create a
label: paragraph

line: sequence of 2D images and depth maps, which are digitally signed and
label: paragraph

line: sent to the Secure Enclave. To counter both digital and physical spoofs,
label: paragraph

line: the TrueDepth camera randomizes the sequence of 2D images and depth
label: paragraph

line: map captures, and projects a device-specific random pattern. A portion
label: paragraph

line: of the A11 Bionic chip’s neural engine—protected within the Secure
label: paragraph

line: Enclave—transforms this data into a mathematical representation and
label: paragraph

line: compares that representation to the enrolled facial data. This enrolled
label: paragraph

line: facial data is itself a mathematical representation of your face captured
label: paragraph

line: across a variety of poses.
label: paragraph

line: Facial matching is performed within the Secure Enclave using neural
label: paragraph

line: networks trained specifically for that purpose. We developed the facial
label: paragraph

line: matching neural networks using over a billion images, including IR and
label: paragraph

line: depth images collected in studies conducted with the participants’
label: paragraph

line: informed consent. Apple worked with participants from around the world
label: paragraph

line: to include a representative group of people accounting for gender, age,
label: paragraph

line: ethnicity, and other factors. The studies were augmented as needed to
label: paragraph

line: provide a high degree of accuracy for a diverse range of users. Face ID is
label: paragraph

line: designed to work with hats, scarves, glasses, contact lenses, and many
label: paragraph

line: sunglasses. Furthermore, it’s designed to work indoors, outdoors, and
label: paragraph

line: even in total darkness. An additional neural network that’s trained to spot
label: paragraph

line: and resist spoofing defends against attempts to unlock your iPhone X
label: paragraph

line: with photos or masks.
label: paragraph

line: Face ID data, including mathematical representations of your face, is
label: paragraph

line: encrypted and available only to the Secure Enclave. This data never
label: paragraph

line: leaves the device. It isn’t sent to Apple, nor is it included in device
label: paragraph

line: backups. The following Face ID data is saved, encrypted only for use
label: paragraph

line: by the Secure Enclave, during normal operation:
label: paragraph

line: The mathematical representations of your face calculated during
label: paragraph

line: enrollment.
label: paragraph

line: The mathematical representations of your face calculated during
label: paragraph

line: some unlock attempts if Face ID deems them useful to augment
label: paragraph

line: future matching.

label: paragraph

line: instead immediately discarded once the mathematical representation
label: paragraph

line: How Touch ID or Face ID unlocks an iOS device
label: heading

line: With Touch ID or Face ID disabled, when a device locks, the keys for the
label: paragraph

line: highest class of Data Protection—which are held in the Secure Enclave—
label: paragraph

line: are discarded. The files and Keychain items in that class are inaccessible
label: paragraph

line: until you unlock the device by entering your passcode.
label: paragraph

line: With Touch ID or Face ID enabled, the keys aren’t discarded when the
label: paragraph

line: device locks; instead, they’re wrapped with a key that’s given to the
label: paragraph

line: Touch ID or Face ID subsystem inside the Secure Enclave. When you
label: paragraph

line: attempt to unlock the device, if the device detects a successful match,
label: paragraph

line: it provides the key for unwrapping the Data Protection keys, and the
label: paragraph

line: device is unlocked. This process provides additional protection by
label: paragraph

line: requiring cooperation between the Data Protection and Touch ID or
label: paragraph

line: Face ID subsystems to unlock the device.
label: paragraph

line: unlock the device are lost; they’re discarded by the Secure Enclave after
label: paragraph

line: any conditions are met that require passcode entry (for example, after
label: paragraph

line: not being unlocked for 48 hours or after five failed match attempts).
label: paragraph

line: To improve unlock performance and keep pace with the natural changes
label: paragraph

line: of your face and look, Face ID augments its stored mathematical
label: paragraph

line: representation over time. Upon successful unlock, Face ID may use the
label: paragraph

line: newly calculated mathematical representation—if its quality is sufficient—
label: paragraph

line: for a finite number of additional unlocks before that data is discarded.
label: paragraph

line: Conversely, if Face ID fails to recognize you, but the match quality is
label: paragraph

line: higher than a certain threshold and you immediately follow the failure by
label: paragraph

line: entering your passcode, Face ID takes another capture and augments
label: paragraph

line: its enrolled Face ID data with the newly calculated mathematical
label: paragraph

line: representation. This new Face ID data is discarded if you stop matching
label: paragraph

line: against it and after a finite number of unlocks. These augmentation
label: paragraph

line: processes allow Face ID to keep up with dramatic changes in your facial
label: paragraph

line: hair or makeup use, while minimizing false acceptance.

line: Touch ID, Face ID, and Apple Pay
label: heading

line: You can also use Touch ID and Face ID with Apple Pay to make easy and
label: paragraph

line: secure purchases in stores, apps, and on the web. For more information
label: paragraph

line: on Touch ID and Apple Pay, see the Apple Pay section of this paper.

line: To authorize an in-store payment with Face ID, you must first confirm
label: paragraph

line: intent to pay by double-clicking the side button. You then authenticate
label: paragraph

line: using Face ID before placing your iPhone X near the contactless payment
label: paragraph

line: reader. If you’d like to select a different Apple Pay payment method after
label: paragraph

line: Face ID authentication, you’ll need to reauthenticate, but you won’t have
label: paragraph

line: to double-click the side button again.
label: paragraph

line: To make a payment within apps and on the web, you confirm intent to
label: paragraph

line: pay by double-clicking the side button, then authenticate using Face ID
label: paragraph

line: to authorize the payment. If your Apple Pay transaction isn’t completed
label: paragraph

line: within 30 seconds of double-clicking the side button, you’ll have to
label: paragraph

line: reconfirm intent to pay by double-clicking again.
